comments.commentBody:
Can't help but agree with some specific churlishness at work here in the comments if not the general dismissal of conceptual art.
At first was a fan of Turrell based on works like the Quaker Meeting house in Houston, but after viewing more of his work and attending a lecture by the artist I couldn't help over time to attribute the captivity of his subjects to the aforementioned "fun house tricks."
I would say my disillusionment with the artist mirrored (pun) another former favorite, Olafur Eliasson.
Even the Roden crater: I remember being infatuated with the images of raw spaces carved out of the elements for the elements. A mountain, a tunnel, a dais, time, the moon, the sun, light etc. Then I saw the more recent images of the crater and was dismayed to see that Mr.Turrell has created something that looks to be on the verge of bad fantasy art. (think cover of pulp sci-fi)
Suffice to say, I haven't been there, but from viewing the progress of his other work is seems that perhaps something was lost and has been losing ever since he left the run-down motel. The dealer of experience buying his own wares.
Not to mention the ridiculous mythic exaggerations of character at work in this piece. Sleeping under the wing of an airplane every night. Give me a break.
I'll stick with the Spiral Jetty. It is what it is.

You wouldn't come along later though. The baby they would have later isn't you, it would have a different set of genes. You would never exist.

Your life was pretty rough and you make many valid points about the effects of parents who want nothing to do with their child. It certainly puts things in perspective.

Crazy behavior is one thing, hate is another. It, too, gets heavy likes.

Most people didn't discover hate until the internet aggregated it. But it's been around for a long while. And it's the same hate. The net is off-center. It's not the source of motivation nor a whisperer opening its source code to dark souls, or a showcase for clicks: that idea gives comfort to those who only recently discovered how truly delusional are the faces in the crowd.

The net shows how class-bound we are. Those new to hate assign it to everything except the hearts that generate it. Because it is off-center, the net is the perfect scapegoat for denial. Anonymous, narcissistic, it is seen as cause; it's not; it only reveals and spreads effects.

It's enough to know the hate; its targets, ferocity; it's enough to know the net shows us its true face.

"This has been the same policy in India."

Care to substantiate?

I live in India. I am yet to see any official policy from the state or central government advocating migration to cities, or even building cities for that matter.
India? Are you serious? Indians would never be able to plan something so breathtakingly ambitious. Democracy has its costs, it would seem.

In India the difference is there is little 'element of force' from the state. Each 'villager' in India gets to decide whether to move to the city OR NOT TO.

The Singapore experience where most of the population is now in high rises works well (at least what I saw in the week I spent in Singapore last year. ( Singapore is majority ethnic chinese)

This has been the same policy in India.

Very sad. Very shortsighted.

Buffal49, the idea that doctors will simply go into finance is one of those arguments that perhaps makes sense to economists, who, the joke goes, would not pick up a $100 bill they found in the street, because, by their reasoning, if it were worth something, somebody would already have taken it.

It seems to me to be one of those arguments that completely ignores the human variability in assessing costs and benefits. Frankly, I find it hard to imagine two fields less compatible in terms of the personality traits required.

My personal opinion is that the medical profession would be better off if every potential medical student who was seriously contemplating whether to go into investment banking or into medicine would choose the former, and leave the medical field for those who are passionate about the science, or the desire to help people, or the challenges and rewards of practicing medicine.

Besides, since when do you have to be the best and the brightest to make money on Wall Street? Or be a doctor, for that matter? Are the cleverest doctors necessarily the best ones? I suspect not always.
This is inanely stupid.

It is painful Zeke.  Growing up in a predominantly Catholic community it was all I knew as a child.  That was reality.  It took years to understand and accept that the culture and spiritual path one loved was a fraud.  Sanity demanded rejection but some family members still cling to the church.  Today most Catholics are "cafeteria Catholics" you pick and choose teachings that seem to have merit but leave the rest behind.  Ignore the old white men in the dresses.

Don't you think religion has outlived its usefulness, now that we're in the 21st century and we know oh so much more about the universe around us?

Religion has been exposed for what it's always been about, repression of the masses through bigotry and brutality.

Face it, the church's views on human sexuality are perverted.
Virgin birth? The mother of god having an orgasm? No way.
Chastity for priests? Altar boys know better.
The sin of impure thoughts?
The catholics invented hijab long before the muslims repressed their women.
The church believes that sex is allowed only for procreation, the heck with love, intimacy, pleasure or health.
Growing up catholic is an exercise in repression. At some point, all that repression just blows out in perverted ways.

A practicing catholic either represses humanness, or lives a lie. How do you keep a religion vital and healthy with that?

Mark, I must not understand you. The civil war has been under way. That train left the station some time back. The Jihadists, as you call them, they're there. The Iranians are there. Al Qaeda is there. The Russians are there, providing the arms. The carnage has been ongoing.

EVACUATE DENVER!!!! [not]
If you live in Chernobyl the total radiation dose you get each year is 390 millirem. That's natural plus residual from the accident and fire. In Denver, Colorado, the natural dose is over 1000 millirem/year. Denver gets more than 2.56 times as much radiation as Chernobyl! But Denver has a low cancer rate.

Calculate your annual radiation dose:
http://www.ans.org/pi/resources/dosechart/

The Average American gets 361 millirems/year. Smokers add 280 millirems/year from lead210. Radon accounts for 200 mrem/year.
http://www.doh.wa.gov/ehp/rp/factsheets/factsheets-htm/fs10bkvsman.htm

All natural rocks contain most natural elements. Coal is a rock. The average concentration of uranium in coal is 1 or 2 parts per million. Illinois coal contains up to 103 parts per million uranium. Coal also contains the radioactive decay products of uranium. A 1000 million watt coal fired power plant burns 4 million tons of carbon each year. If you multiply 4 million tons by 1 part per million, you get 4 tons of uranium.

Our interventions actually short circuit the process by which domestic leaders emerge. We pick a guy we like and support him. That occupies the political space, so others cannot emerge based upon their building domestic political support.

They are not emerged yet. My point is they never will if we keep preempting them.

They must solve their own problems. We can perhaps be of some help in some cases, to some limited degree.

Invading them is not help. Arming factions in civil wars and CIA involvement among the sides is not help. Those things preempt what we say we want to encourage. Would domestic politics in Iran be more to our liking if we had attacked before this election? Yet that is what we do in too many cases.

Our own Civil War had some very nasty players. Sure, there was Robert E. Lee, but there was also the homicidal maniacs from Mosby's guerrilla campaign in the East to Quantrill's Raiders in the West. The North did Sherman's March to the Sea.

We cannot expect the Middle East's wars to be any prettier than our own. We can make them even worse, as we have in Afghanistan and did in Iraq. We kill many, and we prevent it ending by supporting a side that is not viable except for its reliance on us.

We need to stay out, for our sake, and theirs.

Segregation used to protect whites from competition from blacks. Now the way the drug laws are enforced achieves the same effect. Whether this originated as some nefarious plot is beside the point. These policies have had this effect for years, and the effect is the same no matter why people support or think they support the policies.

The Republican party, the party of white people, police, and get-tough thinking, supports these policies and its voters benefit from them. Meanwhile the official justifications for these policies is incoherent if not nonexistent.

Those are the funniest comments either of you have posted this month!

Thing is, Howie was trying to be funny, and succeeded.

Factboy, I don't know.

Why a Nuclear Powerplant CAN NOT Explode like a Nuclear Bomb:

  A nuclear bomb "compresses" pure or nearly pure fissile material into a small space. The fissile material is either the uranium235 or plutonium239. They are the reduced bright shiny metals, not metal oxide. If it is uranium, it is at least 90% uranium 235 and 10% or less uranium 238.

  These fissile materials are metals and very difficult to compress. Because they are difficult to compress, a high explosive is required to compress them. Pieces of the fissile material have to slam into each other hard for the nuclear reactions to take place.  

A nuclear reactor, such as the ones used for power generation, does not have any pure fissile material. The fuel may be 0.7% to 8% uranium235 oxide mixed with uranium238 oxide [uranium rust]. A mixture of 0.7% to 8% uranium 235 rust mixed with uranium 238 rust cannot be made to explode no matter how hard you try. A small amount of plutonium oxide mixed in with the uranium oxide can not change this.

  The fuel is further diluted by being divided and sealed into many steel capsules. The capsules are contained in steel tubes. The fuel is further diluted by the need for coolant to flow around the capsules and through the core so that heat can be transported to a place where heat energy can be converted to electrical energy.

  There has never been a NUCLEAR explosion inside a reactor and there never will be.

Nuclear power production is one of the world's safest industries on an LLE basis. Those with genuine interests in lowering LLE ought to be working hard to increase OHSA's funding to a decent level instead of maundering on about the nuclear power production industry.

Tough SATURDAY puzzle. I took a gamble on BAEZ and SALADBAR that paid off in the NW. Thank goodness for Buzz COLA @55D. I too had LINEOUTS for a while @28A, and was sure of ANTITOXIN @13D. Eventually worked it all out with no look-ups.

A rule in most Romance languages is that if gender is indistinct, use the masculine or ET ALII.  Of course constructors don't always tell you that the feminine form is what works.

YEAH, I think this is an instance where saying "it's a clue, not a definition" is inadequate. The clue was flat-out incorrect, unless you subscribe to the notion (which is feasible, even if I don't buy it) that anyone who places among the top 100 or 200 athletes in their sport at any given time is a "great" of that sport.

I suppose every Olympic athlete is a "great" in their sport as well, by that logic, be it judo or gymnastics or boxing or diving. But I'll give up doing the NYT XWP if they start cluing every Bulgarian, Brasilian, and Botswanan diver who ever participated in an Olympic event as "great".
Agree with you - except that letting women die in childbirth, and  forced to bear child after child is a form of violence.

The Catholic Church may be a dishonest organization teaching us medieval nonsense about three-in-one godfellas but at least they don't burn folks alive anymore, or torture people. So we have to be grateful that they've outgrown the violence, but it must irk them sometimes that they've handed the power to secularists, who are much nicer all round, and a lot less nasty.

In February, 2012, a tragic hyperbaric chamber accident  "blew" the roof off a facility in Ocala,  Florida.  The horse being treated in the chamber was killed as was the lovely young woman attending the sealed hyperbaric chamber.   I had visited that facility the day before the accident standing just feet from the chamber chatting with the young woman while another horse received the treatment.  Sadly horses, horse shoes, sparks, and oxygen can be a lethal mix.

You learn very little from victory, but you can learn everything from adversity. Ramon Dominguez is a life master in the game of life. Watch what happens in his next chapter. He is a magician, an artist, a star of a man. Bet on him.
Jerome Castle

Mark Renfrow: "Power to Save the World; The Truth About Nuclear Energy" by Gwyneth Cravens, 2007 Finally a truthful book about nuclear power.

Page 201: "Two truckloads of uranium ore contain the same energy to make electricity as two million tons of coal. "To get a million BTUs, fuel oil costs nine dollars, natural gas six dollars, coal a dollar-eighty-fife, nuclear fifty cents."

Page 211: "In 2005, the production cost of electricity:

from nuclear power on average cost 1.72 cents per kilowatt-hour, That is TOTAL cost;

from coal-fired plants 2.21;

from natural gas 7.5,

and from oil 8.09.

American nuclear power reactors operated that year around the clock at about 90 percent capacity, whereas coal-fired plants operated at about 73 percent, hydroelectric plants at 29 percent, natural gas from 16 to 38 percent, wind at 27 percent, solar at 19 percent, and geothermal at 75 percent." The costs per kilowatt hour for solar and wind are 600 or more times the cost for coal, and that is in sunny and windy places, respectively.

The cost per kilowatt hour delivered is going down for nuclear because of factory built [modular] reactors. Renewables are impossible because the energy storage is not feasible and room temperature superconductors are beyond the state of the art.
